abstract:
In order to prioritize areas for habitat restoration and protection in the Lake Roosevelt Habitat Improvement Project (LRHIP), it's important to consider stream water chemistry and discharge. However, there is limited data available for most reservation streams without anadromous fish, especially smaller ones. To address this issue, a standardized protocol was developed for future status and trend monitoring of stream water chemistry and discharge.

The new approach focuses on restoring natural stream function and uses an Ecosystem Diagnosis and Treatment (EDT) model to help determine priority areas for habitat restoration and protection. The EDT model considers habitat features and biological performance, bringing together information from empirical observation, local experts, and other models and analysis.

To develop the EDT model, Level II attribute ratings for water chemistry and discharge are necessary. Empirical data is preferred for these ratings. However, if such data is limited, baseline information can be collected through a standardized protocol.

The following is a summary of the protocol:

1. Choose representative sites: Select several sites that represent different habitats and conditions within the stream reach.
2. Collect water samples: Use appropriate methods to collect water samples at each site. Be sure to note the exact location, date, and time of collection.
3. Measure discharge: Determine the flow rate using a current meter or other suitable device. Record the measurement at the same time as water sampling.
4. Analyze water samples: Send samples for laboratory analysis to determine key parameters such as pH, temperature, dissolved oxygen, nutrient levels, and sediment load.
5. Document metadata: Record any relevant information about the site, such as geology, vegetation cover, land use upstream, and weather conditions at the time of sampling.

By following this protocol, consistent baseline data can be collected for future monitoring, allowing for the development of more accurate EDT models and informed decision-making in habitat restoration and protection efforts.

It also seeks to collect baseline information on water chemistry and discharge to support EDT model development, which is used to determine priority areas for habitat restoration and protection based on habitat conditions and fish performance.

Collect water chemistry and discharge data: Develop a standardized procedure for measuring water chemistry (pH, temperature, dissolved oxygen, nutrient levels, etc.) and discharge in streams under the LRHIP. description:
The Lake Roosevelt Habitat Improvement Project (LRHIP) focuses on enhancing migratory rainbow trout populations and their corresponding harvest opportunities for the Colville Confederated Tribes (CCT) through habitat restoration and riparian corridor rehabilitation (LeCaire and Peone, 1991). To guide these efforts effectively, prioritizing habitat restoration actions and implementing rigorous monitoring of fish populations and stream conditions is essential.

The text mentions the importance of addressing the lack of statistical rigor in previous monitoring study designs and unclear prioritization of habitat restoration actions (Northwest Power and Conservation Committees, 2011). In response to these challenges, a new approach was developed focusing on restoring natural stream function and using an Ecosystem Diagnosis and Treatment (EDT) model for habitat restoration and protection prioritization.

The EDT model relies on empirical observations of habitat conditions and current fish use, as well as water chemistry and discharge data to determine high-priority areas for restoration and conservation (Lichatowich et al., 1995; Lestelle et al., 1996; Mobrand et al., 1997; Mobrand et al., 1998). While baseline water chemistry and discharge data are crucial for EDT model development, they were not mentioned in the text as being currently available for most reservation streams without anadromous fish, particularly smaller ones.

To ensure consistency with other monitoring programs in the Basin (Columbia Habitat Monitoring Program, CHaMP; Terraqua Inc., 2009), a standardized protocol for future status and trend monitoring of stream water chemistry and discharge was developed. This protocol should include:

1. Collection of water samples at regular intervals to measure specific conductivity (SC), pH, total dissolved solids (TDS), total hardness (TH), calcium ion concentration (Ca²+), magnesium ion concentration (Mg²+), and alkalinity.
2. Measurement of stream discharge using methods such as the velocity-area method or the transect method.
3. Recording of meteorological data, including temperature, precipitation, and solar radiation.
4. Proper handling, storage, and transportation of water samples to minimize contamination and ensure accurate results.
5. Application of appropriate analytical methods for measuring water chemistry parameters according to standardized protocols.
6. Data entry, management, and analysis using specialized software tools.

To provide a baseline for future monitoring efforts, it is recommended to gather water chemistry and discharge data sets from representative streams in the reservation system. This data will serve as the foundation for evaluating trends and prioritizing restoration actions using the EDT model.

Objective 1: Develop a standardized protocol for stream water chemistry and discharge monitoring to provide baseline data and enable future status and trend monitoring for habitat restoration and protection prioritization.

Coverage: This objective covers the need for collecting baseline information on water chemistry and discharge to support the EDT model development for habitat restoration and protection prioritization, as well as ensuring consistency with other monitoring programs in the Basin.

Protocol for Future Stream Water Chemistry and Discharge Monitoring:
1. Select representative sites based on the size, flow characteristics, and geographic location of the streams.
2. Obtain necessary permits and permissions to conduct monitoring activities.
3. Establish a standardized sampling schedule (e.g., monthly, quarterly).
4. Use appropriate methods for measuring water chemistry parameters (pH, temperature, dissolved oxygen, nutrients, etc.) according to established protocols.
5. Record flow data using a reliable and accurate method, such as a current meter or stream gauge.
6. Store and transport samples according to appropriate procedures to minimize contamination and degradation.
7. Analyze water samples in an accredited laboratory following standard methods.
8. Enter data into a database for storage and analysis.
9. Report results to the relevant stakeholders, including the Colville Confederated Tribes, Northwest Power and Conservation Committee, and other partners.
10. Periodically review and update monitoring protocols as needed to ensure effectiveness and accuracy.

Providing baseline data sets: Collect water chemistry and discharge data for several years before implementing restoration actions to establish a solid baseline for future comparison and trend analysis.
